title: Theremin
brief_description: The theremin was invented in 1920 and is played by harnessing electricity. Though it’s most commonly associated with sci-fi, it’s first use was in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945).

constellations_primary.name: Good vibrations
constellations_primary.description: Since its invention, the humble theremin has been used in a number of different ways to evoke all sorts of strange sounds and moods.

description: The eerie sound accompanying the alien invasion in The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) is almost more iconic than the flying saucers themselves. Composer Bernard Herrmann created those other-worldly vibrations with duelling theremins, an instrument invented by Léon Theremin in 1920 that is played by harnessing electricity. Though the theremin is most commonly associated with science fiction, it was first used in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound (1945). For a dream sequence designed by Surrealist artist Salvador Dali, composer Miklós Rózsa used the theremin’s strange reverberations to produce unease and psychological tension. The instrument has also been used in films like Ghostbusters (1984), Ed Wood (1994) and First Man (2018), along with TV shows and videogames.
